rd_url:
At Least 3 People Killed In Amtrak Derailment In Montana
JOPLIN, Mont. — At least three people were killed Saturday afternoon when an Amtrak train that runs between Seattle and Chicago derailed in north-central Montana, toppling several cars onto their sides, authorities said.
The westbound Empire Builder train derailed about 4 p.m. near Joplin, a town of about 200, Amtrak spokesman Jason Abrams said in a statement. The accident scene is about 150 miles (241 kilometers) northeast of Helena and about 30 miles (48 kilometers) from the border with Canada.
Liberty County sheriff's dispatcher Starr Tyler told The Associated Press that three people died in the derailment. She did not have more details. Amtrak confirmed the deaths and said there were multiple injuries.
"We are deeply saddened to learn local authorities are now confirming that three people have lost their lives as a result of this accident," Abrams said.
The train had about 141 passengers and 16 crew members onboard, Abrams said. The train had two locomotives and 10 cars, eight of which derailed, he said.
"We are deeply saddened to learn local authorities are now confirming that three people have lost their lives as a result of this accident," Abrams said.
Megan Vandervest, a passenger who was going to visit a friend in Seattle, told The New York Times that she was awakened by the derailment.
"My first thought was that we were derailing because, to be honest, I have anxiety and I had heard stories about trains derailing," said Vandervest, who is from Minneapolis. "My second thought was that's crazy. We wouldn't be derailing. Like, that doesn't happen."
She told the Times that the car behind hers was tilted, the one behind that was tipped over, and the three cars behind that "had completely fallen off the tracks and were detached from the train."
Speaking from the Liberty County Senior Center, where some passengers were being taken, Vandervest said it felt like "extreme turbulence on a plane."
Residents of communities near the crash site quickly mobilized to help the passengers.
Chester Councilwoman Rachel Ghekiere said she and others helped about 50 to 60 passengers who were brought to a local school.
"I went to the school and assisted with water, food, wiping dirt off faces," she said. "They appeared to be tired, shaken but happy that they were where they were. Some looked more disheveled than others, depending where they were on the train."
A grocery store in Chester, about 5 miles (8 kilometers) from the derailment, and a nearby religious community provided food, she said.
The passengers were taken by buses to hotels in nearby Shelby, said Ghekiere, whose husband works for the local emergency services agency and was alerted to the crash.
The National Transportation Safety Board will send a 14-member team, including investigators and specialists in railroad signals and other disciplines, to investigate the crash, spokesman Eric Weiss said.
Weiss said the derailment occurred around 3:55 p.m. and no other trains or equipment were involved. The train was traveling on a BNSF Railway main track at the time, he said.
Photos posted to social media showed rail cars on their sides and passengers standing alongside the tracks, some carrying luggage. The images showed sunny skies, and it appeared the accident occurred along a straight section of tracks.
Amtrak said that because of the derailment, the Sunday westbound Empire Builder will terminate in Minneapolis, and the Sunday eastbound Empire Builder train will originate in Minneapolis.
Allan Zarembski, director of the University of Delaware's Railway Engineering and Safety Program, said he didn't want to speculate but suspected the derailment stemmed from an issue with the train track or equipment, or a combination of both.
Railways have "virtually eliminated" major derailments by human error after the implementation of positive train control nationwide, Zarembski said.
"I would be surprised if this was a human-factor derailment," Zarembski said.
Depending on how complex the cause of the derailment was, NTSB findings may take months, he added, as investigators must interview witnesses and sift through the pile-up and damage to collect evidence and then send samples off for further testing.
Other recent Amtrak derailments include:
— April 3, 2016: Two maintenance workers were struck and killed by an Amtrak train going more than 100 mph in Chester, Pennsylvania. The lead engine of the train derailed.
— March 14, 2016: An Amtrak train traveling from Los Angeles to Chicago derailed in southwest Kansas, sending five cars off the tracks and injuring at least 32 people. Investigators concluded that a cattle feed delivery truck hit the track and shifted it at least a foot before the derailment.
— Oct. 5, 2015: A passenger train headed from Vermont to Washington, D.C., derailed when it hit rocks that had fallen onto the track from a ledge. The locomotive and a passenger car spilled down an embankment, derailing three other cars and injuring seven people.
— May 12, 2015: Amtrak Train 188 was traveling at twice the 50 mph speed limit as it entered a sharp curve in Philadelphia and derailed. Eight people were killed and more than 200 were injured when the locomotive and four of the train's seven passenger cars jumped the tracks. Several cars overturned and ripped apart.

rd_url:
Trinity Schmidt hovered near the door of her small Louisiana home on the last day of her life.
A blue Ford Taurus soon pulled up, and Trinity, 12, flew out of the house, forgetting to say goodbye.
“They’re here!” was all she hollered to her mother before hopping in the back seat with twins Brandon and Chase Day, and another friend from school, Jayla Daigle.
The group was headed to a trampoline park to celebrate the boys’ 12th birthday, chaperoned by the twins’ grandmother, Phyllis LeBlanc, 70, and her husband, Steven LeBlanc Jr. It was three days before Christmas 2015. Only one of them would live to see the new year.
As the Taurus drove off, the Sunset Limited was gliding through east Texas, nearing the end of its 1,900-mile journey from Los Angeles. The Amtrak train — two locomotives lugging seven passenger cars and 133 souls — was a million-pound chain of steel racing toward New Orleans, barreling through communities along the way.
Darkness had fallen and a menacing thunderstorm had erupted by the time the LeBlancs and the four kids left the trampoline park just before 5:30 p.m. Rain came down in sheets as Phyllis LeBlanc turned onto Highway 88, a rural, two-lane road in New Iberia. Brake lights glowed in the deluge as the vehicle in front of LeBlanc stopped at the intersection where Highway 88 meets Highway 182. She pulled up behind it, and a slight bump jostled her car.
Warning lights suddenly exploded all around the Taurus, flashing red. Two long mechanical arms descended in front of and behind the car. Then a train whistle screamed.
They were trapped on railroad tracks.
LeBlanc desperately tried to navigate an escape in the few seconds she had, witnesses told the Louisiana State Police. But the gates and other cars penned them in as the Sunset Limited roared toward the crossing at 70 mph.
It could not possibly stop in time.
The Amtrak annihilated the Ford, knocking it nearly 200 feet down the tracks. Phyllis LeBlanc, Trinity Schmidt and Jayla Daigle died in a sodden ditch beside the rails. The storm’s violence prevented the others from being airlifted to the hospital.
Chase Day died on Christmas Day, and Steven LeBlanc Jr. passed away Dec. 26.
Brandon Day was the only survivor.
“The doctor told us that Brandon had suffered some severe injuries, but that he was going to survive,” said Keith Day, the father of the twins. “Then they told us Chase was not. He had a massive, massive head injury. And he never even woke up.”
Fate, poor design and torrential rain might have conspired to put the Taurus on the tracks that night. But it was a cascade of failures, malfunctions and negligence that set the Sunset Limited on a collision course with a sedan filled with four kids, according to a lawsuit filed by the victims’ families.
The conditions that led to the fatal crash in New Iberia — simply getting caught in traffic at a stop sign or traffic light — exist at tens of thousands of railroad crossings in the U.S., including hundreds in New Jersey. They put drivers in potentially fatal situations with alarming regularity.
At the same time, deaths at railroad crossings have been increasing in recent years, up nearly 25% from 2015 to 2019, when almost 300 Americans were killed after decades of sharp declines.
A yearlong investigation by NJ Advance Media, supported by the O’Brien Fellowship at Marquette University, found safety failings have been evident for decades. Weak — and sometimes nonexistent — federal regulation has failed to rein in a mighty railroad industry that often blames rail crossing crashes on drivers.
Our investigation found that even relatively straightforward safety upgrades have been ignored at thousands of crossings, despite decades-old federal safety guidelines and clear evidence that the measures save lives. The New Iberia crossing is one of more than 40,000 across the country that doesn’t meet the standards, federal data shows. That number includes nearly one-third of all crossings in New Jersey.
The Federal Railroad Administration, the arm of the U.S. Department of Transportation that regulates railroads, lacks the funding, authority and political wherewithal to enforce these guidelines, giving railroads and state governments little incentive to effectuate them, according to industry experts.
Our investigation also found that the U.S. DOT’s top crossing safety program, which gives states millions of dollars every year to pay for upgrades, is dangerously flawed. The FRA has incorrect data for more than one-third of all railroad crossings in the country — and likely for many more. Officials use that data to determine what crossings receive safety improvements.
Meanwhile, even crossings with automatic gates and flashing lights — the most common safety devices — do not always protect drivers because the equipment fails regularly, violating federal regulations. Government officials have known the safety equipment is prone to malfunction since before it was widely adopted in the 1980s and ’90s.
“We’ve been getting people slaughtered,” said David Nelson, a former CSX railroad employee driven by safety concerns to become a government whistleblower. “They’re not fail-safe.”
Perhaps the most glaring outrage, though, is that the railroads get to control the narrative of all but the deadliest crashes. Federal officials investigate a minuscule percentage of collisions, almost always allowing railroads to examine their own accidents. In recent years, railroads have been caught lying as well as destroying and withholding evidence, according to court findings and whistleblowers.
“Those deaths will continue as long as the states and the FRA continue to regulate the railroads,” said Harvey Levine, a former official in the powerful railroad lobby The Association of American Railroads, who has since become an outspoken advocate for rail safety.
These horrific crashes come down to grim arithmetic, according to Levine.
“You’ve got 6,000 trains running a day and millions of cars,” he said. “Accidents are going to happen.”
But these tragedies transcend morbid probability for the shattered families.
Brandon and Chase Day chose not to ride home with their parents on that fateful day in 2015, insisting on staying with their friends in their grandmother’s car. So Keith and Jody Day drove to Phyllis LeBlanc’s house to wait for the birthday boys.
But only one ever made it back to them.
“It’s tore our family apart, and all it would have taken was for somebody to care,” Keith Day said in a recent interview. “It’s the cost of a life, and they don’t even care about the cost of a life.”
109 N.J. deaths
These crashes aren’t just some faraway problem, relegated to the rural corners of America. They occur regularly in New Jersey, too.
In November, a 17-year-old high school student was driving with a friend in Piscataway when they were hit by a freight train at the New Brunswick Avenue crossing. The passenger, a teenage girl whose name was not made public, was killed.
That crossing is one of at least 560 in New Jersey within 75 feet of an intersection, where traffic often backs up onto the tracks. Since 1975, those crossings have seen 687 crashes and 109 deaths, according to a database NJ Advance Media built for this investigation.
A stretch of track less than a mile long in Bergen County illustrates the lurking danger. The Midland Avenue crossing in Elmwood Park has been the scene of 34 crashes and two deaths since 1975. Only 22 rail crossings in the country have seen more crashes.
The next crossing south, on Market Street, has witnessed nine crashes and five deaths. Keep going south one more crossing and you’re again on Midland Avenue, this time in Garfield, where there have been 12 crashes and two deaths.
“There have been thousands and thousands of accidents that have been caused by cars being trapped on the crossing,” said Bob Comer, an Ohio-based railroad accident investigator. “In New York and New Jersey, which have a high concentration of people, so many of those crossings should have been eliminated so long ago.”
Trains and railroads are baked into American mythology. They evoke images of business titans and socialites lounging in the Pullman car, or vagabonds riding in boxcars. They have been the go-to toys for generations of American children and the setting for any number of classic books and movies, from “The General” to “Strangers on a Train” to “Unstoppable.”
The history and romance associated with railroads can obscure an important fact: They are massive businesses in this country, a literal engine driving American capitalism, responsible for hauling chemicals, coal and cars across the country.
The “Big Four” U.S. railroads — BNSF, CSX, Norfolk Southern and Union Pacific — had a combined revenue in 2019 of nearly $70 billion, roughly the same as Facebook and Disney and more than Pepsi, financial documents show. BNSF and Union Pacific each made more money in 2019 than McDonald’s. The stock prices of CSX and Norfolk Southern have increased approximately 280% and 230%, respectively, over the past five years.
The “Big Four” aren’t shy about flexing political muscle, either. Since 2010, they have spent $177 million on lobbying and donated $57.7 million to political candidates, according to the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonprofit that tracks political activity.
“The railroad is the most powerful entity in the United States, and they don’t want to identify hazards that are killing people,” said Bob Pottroff, a lawyer who regularly clashed with the railroads.
The railroads’ interest in minimizing liability dovetails with the government’s interest in sustaining an industry that supported $220 billion in economic output and 1.1 million jobs in 2017, according to a Towson University report. Those concerns appear to trump the safety of drivers at rail crossings despite obvious warning signs, Pottroff said.
Almost uniformly, the Big Four railroads and the Association of American Railroads said they follow federal guidelines and that the best way to protect drivers at crossings is to eliminate the crossings entirely.
The crash that killed Phyllis LeBlanc and four others is a prime example of how dangerous a crossing can be. To even an untrained eye, a Google Earth image of the intersection of highways 88 and 182 in New Iberia screams accident waiting to happen.
On Highway 88, drivers encounter train tracks and then — about 30 feet beyond them — an intersection where cars can turn only left or right. That space is big enough for just one car, which must stop. If traffic backs up at the intersection, it’s all too easy for a vehicle to end up stopped on the rails. In fact, the Google Street View of the crossing shows two trucks stopped directly on the tracks.
After the accident, I watched the crossing for about four hours over a two-day period. Nearly 50 cars came to a complete stop on the tracks while I sat in a rental car on a gravel patch next to the crossing. Since 1975, as far back as consistent government records go, 14 trains have hit cars there and eight people have died.
“You have to be supremely focused or really lucky to negotiate that crossing,” said Sarah Feinberg, head of the FRA under President Barack Obama.
Similar railroad crossings exist all over the country. More than a third of the 127,605 public crossings in the U.S. are within 75 feet of an intersection, according to the NJ Advance Media database built using government records. In New Jersey, those crossings comprise about 40% of the total.
And they are disproportionately perilous. Nearly 45% of the 18,152 deaths at active crossings since 1975 occurred within 75 feet of an intersection — as did almost half of the 162,266 crashes.
The federal government has recognized the danger of these crossings for more than 70 years. The Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices — the bible of traffic signs and signals used by federal officials and state governments — has warned since at least 1948 just how hazardous these crossings can be.
The recommended fix isn’t complicated. Certainly, you don’t need to rip up roads or railways and start from scratch. Instead, federal guidelines call for crossings close to intersections to have safety equipment — automatic gates and flashing lights — that cooperates with an everyday traffic light. The industry calls this interconnection.
The system detects a train coming well before it arrives and signals to the equipment at the crossing and the intersection. That signal overrides the traffic light, which will quickly change to green, allowing cars on the crossing to clear the tracks. The light then switches to red ahead of the oncoming train.
The problem is the FRA says it cannot mandate interconnection at crossings — or any other safety equipment — leaving the decision to state and municipal authorities.
“A crossing that is interconnected with adjacent traffic signals is always safer than one without,” said Robert Halstead, a New York-based railroad accident investigator.
The New Iberia crossing not only lacks interconnection with a traffic light, but that intersection doesn’t even have a traffic signal.
It’s a problem nationwide. The NJ Advance Media database shows 93% of crossings within 75 feet of an intersection are not interconnected with traffic lights, as federal guidelines recommend. Even worse, nearly 40% do not have even basic safety devices, like flashing lights and automatic gates.
Eighty-three deaths have occurred at similar crossings in New Jersey that do not meet safety guidelines.
“These deaths are preventable,” said Feinberg, the former FRA administrator who is currently interim president of New York City Transit Authority. “There’s always more we can do.”
After the deadly crash last November at the New Brunswick Avenue crossing in Piscataway, authorities pinned the blame on the driver, as is common. They said the safety equipment was working properly at the time of the incident. But prosecutors went a step further and charged the driver, a minor, with vehicular homicide, aggravated manslaughter and driving without a license.
What the authorities didn’t say is the crossing does not follow federal guidelines.
There is no traffic signal. No interconnection. And no automatic gates. The Piscataway crossing is protected only by flashing lights. Even though nine crashes had previously happened there, additional safety equipment was not installed.
But prosecutors still blamed the 17-year-old driver.
A question of $
The issue largely comes down to money.
The U.S. DOT had a 2020 budget of nearly $87 billion. But only $2.8 billion of that — a smidge over 3% — went to the FRA in the last fiscal year. That’s about $100 million less than the previous year.
More safety equipment and increased oversight costs money, which the FRA can find hard to come by, said George Gavalla, a former FRA safety official.
“To get funding isn’t an easy thing,” he said. “There has to be a public backing for these types of things. One of the ways to get that public backing, unfortunately, is to have a major accident.”
In the 1960s, politicians began feeling the pressure of an ever-increasing death toll at rail crossings. (In 1965 alone, more than 1,500 people were killed at crossings, federal data shows.) Congressional leaders were dismayed to find that railroads largely regulated themselves, so lawmakers passed the Federal Railroad Safety Act of 1970, which created the FRA to oversee railroads.
The law has proved successful: Since 1975, fatalities at crossings have dropped by 70%, according to federal data. Fatalities hit a low point in 2012, when 230 people were killed.
Gavalla, former head of safety for the FRA, said the reason for the decline was the removal or enhanced protection of thousands of dangerous crossings in the past few decades.
They got the “low-hanging fruit,” Gavalla said. “We reached a plateau, and the improvements aren’t quite as obvious.”
Deaths have been on the rise since 2012. The 294 people killed at crossings in 2019 were the most in 12 years. (Crossing accidents did fall 15% in 2020, but the National Safety Council reported the number of miles driven was down because of the coronavirus pandemic. Freight and passenger rail traffic was also down last year. Still, the accident rate at crossings continued to rise in 2020, FRA data shows.)
Yet the FRA’s ability to regulate railroads remains limited, in part because federal agencies have little power over individual states.
Congress forced railroads to update rail crossing data in 2008 as part of the Rail Safety Improvement Act. Railroads now are required to provide fresh information on how many trains run on the tracks, how fast they go and what safety equipment is in place.
Yet, there is no commensurate legislation to compel states to update their data, even though it is used to determine where safety equipment gets installed.
The result is a patchwork of shoddy data. In some cases, it’s plainly incorrect. In others, it’s badly outdated.
“The inventory is only as good as what’s submitted by our partners,” said Tammy Wagner, regional crossing specialist with the FRA. “I can tell you a lot of complaints about that. That’s a huge problem.”
How widespread is the problem? The FRA currently has incorrect data for more than one-third of all crossings in the country, according to an NJ Advance Media analysis of a random, representative sample.
“We can get after the railroads for their information. We can’t do that for the state’s information,” said Karl Alexy, the FRA’s chief safety officer. “Knowing we can go in and only count on half the data is frustrating.”
The data point most often incorrect is the distance crossings sit from nearby roads, according to the analysis. Many of the details about crossings, like how many cars cross the tracks every day, couldn’t be independently verified, so the true breadth of misreported data is likely higher.
And much of that crucial information is outdated to the point of being incorrect. Traffic counts at crossings are 17 years old on average in the federal data, while people are driving about 11% more every year than they were in 2004, according to U.S. Department of Energy statistics.
Even though critical safety decisions are ultimately made on the state level, the data compiled by the FRA — which we used for the analysis — is largely the same as what the states have.
NJ Advance Media requested records from every state but Hawaii, which has only eight public crossings, to see if the data they use is the same as what the federal government collects. Thirty-seven states, including New Jersey, said they use some or all of the federal data in making safety decisions, while only seven states said they use different data. (Five states didn’t respond.)
“You’ve uncovered a scandal,” said Carl Berkowitz, a New York-based transportation engineer who has served as an expert witness in crossing fatality cases. “This really needs to be brought to the attention of the congressional committee.”
When ‘fail-safe’ equipment fails
The warning lights were dark and the safety gates were vertical when Brian Frazier approached the railroad crossing.
He was driving three friends through Anoka, Minnesota late one fall night in 2003. They had left a high school football game and were heading to a party for a friend deploying for military duty in Afghanistan.
As Frazier neared the crossing on Ferry Street around 10 p.m., nothing indicated it was unsafe to cross.
But when his Chevrolet Cavalier touched the rails, a 33-car freight train came barreling from the west, hitting the vehicle at nearly 60 mph. Frazier, 20, and his three passengers, Bridgette Shannon, 17, Corey Chase, 20, and Harry Rhoades, Jr., 19, were killed.
Equipment failures like that aren’t supposed to happen. Federal regulations require safety equipment at railroad crossings to alert drivers even when it’s not working properly, a concept known as the fail-safe principle. When the equipment malfunctions, warning lights are supposed to flash and the gates are designed to drop, blocking the crossing.
But purportedly fail-safe equipment fails regularly, sometimes with devastating consequences. Safety equipment has failed to activate more than 8,000 times since 2000 when a train came through a crossing, according to FRA records. That’s more than once per day, a huge number that has drawn little federal scrutiny. However, failure rates have fallen in recent years, the agency says.
Since railroads — which are responsible for maintaining their crossing equipment — rarely face repercussions if they fail to report the malfunctions, the federal count might be just a fraction of the true number. A New York Times investigation in 2004 found several instances when railroads did not report these failures. Our investigation found numerous others, including the Anoka and New Iberia crashes.
Indeed, the federal government has known for decades that the technology widely used at crossings can be unreliable.
A 1981 report commissioned by the U.S. DOT found that emerging safety technology was prone to failure and needed more work before it could be deployed on a wide scale. That same system has since been rolled out nationwide. Crossing safety equipment is vulnerable to numerous factors, from lightning strikes and electromagnetic interference to something as simple as sand or rust accumulating on the rails, industry experts acknowledge.
FRA spokesman Warren Flatau said safety technology has moved well beyond the 1981 standards and suggested a comparison between then and now is unfair. Still, many of the failures reported in the FRA’s database were caused by the same factors responsible for equipment failure decades ago.
In the case of the Minnesota crossing, BNSF acknowledged in court that the equipment had malfunctioned in the months before the 2003 crash.
“The railroads and FRA will claim that circuits are fail-safe. They are not,” said Comer, the railroad accident investigator from Ohio. “The circuits can and often do fail.”
The FRA has been a proponent of the safety technology — a system called constant warning time — because it gives drivers a realistic expectation of when a train will arrive at the crossing.
Despite the technology’s long-established pattern of failures, the FRA is still sanctioning its use all over the country.
“Almost without exception, where there is equipment, that equipment is functioning,” said Alexy, the FRA’s top safety official. He did acknowledge that the equipment does fail, but said it does not violate the law. “That happens, and that’s something that does occur. ... That does happen too frequently for us.”
When the safety technology works properly, which it does most of the time, it makes drivers aware of trains and helps keep them off the tracks. But the fail-safe requirement is intended to protect drivers even when the equipment is malfunctioning.
Berkowitz, the accident investigator from New York, said railroads should build redundancy into the equipment. If the main safety system isn’t working, have a backup.
The problem is such measures are expensive.
“Redundancy doubles the cost,” Berkowitz said. “Cost — that’s the bottom line in transportation.”
Alexy echoed that cost was an obstacle. He said the FRA does an adequate job regulating the railroads, but it could do better if it had more funding or authority.
“We’d have a difficult time justifying the cost of that redundancy,” he said.
The sheer number of crossings in the United States also contributes to the problem. It has about 200,000 if you include crossings on private land, which aren’t regulated in the same way.
Nearly 40% of the 120,000 public crossings don’t have warning lights or gates, federal data shows.
Misplaced blame
Minutes after the Sunset Limited hit Phyllis LeBlanc’s Ford Taurus, word of the New Iberia crash began ricocheting through BNSF.
Chris Duffell, a signal maintenance supervisor overseeing that location, was at a nearby Holiday Inn when his phone rang with a notification from the company’s nerve center. Thirty minutes later, Duffell parked his truck near the crossing.
Duffel said in a deposition that his first move was to make sure no one went inside the metal shed next to the crossing. It houses equipment capable of revealing exactly what happened before the crash.
News reports from the days after the incident quoted a BNSF spokesman who said the crossing safety equipment was working properly — which is contested in the lawsuit — and that the Amtrak locomotive had a camera. Video from the crash has never been made public.
Duffell’s reaction was typical of railroad employees when they show up after deadly crashes — sometimes arriving even before police.
While local cops can interview witnesses and observe the crossing, they have no jurisdiction over the railroad’s crossing equipment and are legally forbidden from drug testing the train crew. Only the railroad’s own private police force, other employees, the FRA and the National Transportation Safety Board have jurisdiction to fully investigate rail crashes. In rare cases, other federal law enforcement agencies, like the FBI, can get involved.
Local police are not even entitled to data from the black boxes on the locomotive or at the crossing. This data can reveal train speed, whether the engineer sounded the horn, and if the lights and gates worked properly.
While the FRA and the NTSB do have the power to investigate these incidents, they don’t often use that authority. The FRA investigated only 95 crossing accidents from 2006 to 2017, 0.4% of all crashes in that timeframe, according to an agency report. The NTSB investigates even fewer rail crossing accidents.
“The reason FRA investigates so few (relatively speaking) is because in 95% of cases the actions and behavior of roadway users are determined to be the primary causal factor,” FRA spokesman Flatau said in a statement.
Unless there’s a report of equipment malfunction or railroad violations, the FRA has “no basis” to investigate, he added. But that’s almost always based on the railroad’s word on what caused the accident.
Limited resources also play a role.
“There are multiple accidents every day, and at some point, we have to understand that we can’t get to every one of them,” Alexy said. “Derailments, things happening across the entire railroad.
“Someone getting killed at a grade crossing is very important, but there are other larger issues on the railroads that we have to get to.”
The lack of independent scrutiny has resulted in railroads pushing their own, sometimes false, narratives of crashes. They also have spent millions to spread their version of events.
In the 1970s, Union Pacific launched Operation Lifesaver, a public relations effort to polish the railroad’s reputation when it came to rail crashes. Now an independent organization, Operation Lifesaver is the primary voice nationwide on crossing safety, pushing a message leaning heavily on driver responsibility. But even though Operation Lifesaver is no longer under the umbrella of Union Pacific, it still gets about one-third of its funding from railroads, said Executive Director Rachel Maleh.
Gavalla, the former FRA safety officer, said Operation Lifesaver’s messaging is too focused on driver responsibility.
“I think their educational message is off-base,” he said. “It’s not a matter of recklessness, most of the time.”
But sometimes the industry’s efforts aren’t so subtle. BNSF made a more flagrant attempt at changing the narrative after the crash that killed Brian Frazier and three others in Anoka, Minnesota nearly two decades ago.
The railroad claimed warning lights at the crossing were flashing and Frazier swung around downed gates — a reckless decision that cost four lives, officials said at the scene of the crash, in the report filed to the federal government and later in protracted litigation.
And that narrative might have been the official record of their deaths had their families not sued BNSF.
The ensuing trial revealed not only was it physically impossible for Frazier to have swerved around the gates, but also that BNSF had recorded problems with the safety equipment prior to the crash.
A jury awarded the victims’ families $21.6 million in damages in 2008, and the court later imposed $4.2 million in sanctions on BNSF for its conduct throughout the ordeal, one of the largest court-imposed sanctions ever put on a railroad.
The Anoka County District Court found BNSF guilty of destroying and misrepresenting evidence, obstructing a police investigation, violating its own procedures for handling crashes and evidence and pressuring witnesses to lie under oath, to point out just a few of the violations. A judge in the case said the railroad’s efforts to cover up the accident went on for years.
“But the breadth of BNSF’s misconduct in this case is staggering; beginning within minutes of the accident, up to and through the trial,” Judge Ellen Maas wrote. “Plaintiffs have established that BNSF’s misconduct did indeed strain the limits of the civil justice system and this Court is on firm ground to impose significant sanctions.”
Frazier did nothing wrong. The gates never went down, the trial revealed.
It’s a common tactic of the railroads, and sometimes even the FRA, to claim reckless driving causes most accidents. But only 23% of crossing accidents between 2016 and 2020 can be blamed on drivers going around or through gates or other barricades, or on suicides, federal data shows.
“If there is anything harmful to the railroad, they will lose event recorders, or say it was erased,” said Richard Beall, a former railroad engineer turned whistleblower. “The railroad will try to tell you that safety is the first importance, but when something happens, you’ll realize safety is all talk.”
‘My little boy ... he’s gone’
In the spring of 2016, the families of Brandon and Chase Day, Jayla Daigle, Trinity Schmidt and Steven LeBlanc Jr. sued BNSF over the crash. Litigation is ongoing, but court records and deposition transcripts obtained by NJ Advance Media raise serious questions about the railroad’s actions.
The crossing was equipped with three event recorders, which track whether the safety equipment was working properly. After the crash, BNSF says it has no usable data from any of the devices. One was unplugged prior to the crash. Another was allegedly corrupted and spit out gibberish. And the third was not downloaded until its memory was overwritten, a direct violation of company protocol, based on depositions from several BNSF employees.
Gavalla said he noticed a similar pattern during his time at the FRA: After crossing crashes, railroads would often claim their event recorders weren’t working properly.
In the months before the New Iberia crash — just as in the Anoka, Minnesota incident — equipment at the crossing had malfunctioned, according to records and BNSF employees’ testimony in depositions.
Immediately after the crash, with the train sitting feet from the crossing and bodies scattered in its wake, BNSF employees admitted the safety equipment was malfunctioning. The lights and gates were repeatedly activating and then turning off.
But this information never made it to police on the scene or in a federal report filed after the crash.
Nathan Karlin, the Kansas-based attorney representing the victims with multiple co-counsels, says those malfunctions actually caused the crash.
The lawsuit claims the crossing’s safety equipment was malfunctioning as Phyllis LeBlanc approached. She could see the warning lights flashing and the gates descending, only for them to reset. When LeBlanc got closer to the crossing, Karlin says the lights and gates again activated and abruptly stopped, allowing both LeBlanc and the car in front of her to proceed. The car in front got hung up at the stop sign — which federal guidelines say should be a traffic light connected to the crossing equipment — and LeBlanc was forced to stop on the tracks.
When the lights and gates activated again, a train was actually coming and her car was trapped.
But BNSF has maintained that Phyllis LeBlanc was at fault for stopping her car on the tracks.
The families’ case against BNSF is scheduled to go to trial in August, having been delayed because of the coronavirus pandemic.
In July 2019, BNSF was sanctioned in Louisiana court for spoliation of evidence over the event recorders. The railroad has since appealed the sanction.
BNSF declined to comment on the New Iberia crash, citing the ongoing litigation. The company said it “complies with all FRA and NTSB regulations and guidelines” and spends more than $100 million annually on “grade-crossing maintenance, improvement and safety programs.”
But BNSF, like all the railroads, is legally required to pay for the upkeep of its crossing equipment, part of an agreement with federal and state governments where taxpayers fund it if the railroads maintain it.
What deepens the New Iberia tragedy is that the issues contributing to the crash — and countless other incidents around the country — aren’t intractable.
New legislation could require states to update the data on their crossings, much as Congress mandated for railroads in 2008. The FRA could commit to investigating more crashes or it could reexamine crossing safety technologies. Congress could also allocate more funding and give the FRA teeth to enforce guidelines that often go ignored, handing the agency tools to properly regulate the railroads.
“As far as I’m concerned, to install some simple safety measures ... would have saved the lives of five people,” said Keith Day, father of Brandon and Chase Day. “They knew about this crossing because I know about two wrecks where people have lost their lives. The cost of something as simple as some safety features would have saved their lives.
“They ought to be held responsible for the death of all those people.”
Whether the political will exists to battle the railroad industry, which would almost certainly lobby against any new legislation or regulation, is another matter entirely.
New Jersey Congressman Donald M. Payne Jr., D-10th Dist., is among the federal lawmakers calling for improved safety at rail crossings.
“I am extremely concerned anytime Americans face a life-threatening safety issue related to our nation’s railroad infrastructure,” said Payne, who chairs the House Subcommittee on Railroads, Pipelines, and Hazardous Materials. “We need to improve the safety of our nation’s highway-railway grade crossings, and we take steps to do it in the Moving Forward Act.”
The bill calls for additional funding to remove crossings and improve safety at those that can’t be eliminated. The bill passed the House last summer, but has not received a vote in the Senate.
Pottroff, the lawyer who initially brought the suit on behalf of the New Iberia families, believed that without legislation, railroads would continue avoiding responsibility for crossing deaths. (Pottroff passed away in 2019, and the case has been taken on by Karlin, his law partner.)
For her part, Barbara LeBlanc — who lost her adult son Steven in the crash — avoided the crossing since the day shortly after the incident when she and her husband laid a wooden cross in the grassy ditch near the tracks.
Steven LeBlanc Jr.’s cross — joined by markers memorializing the other four victims — sits close to where their bodies were thrown. Two other crosses, weathered by time, were placed on the other side of the tracks — reminders of the 13 other crashes at that crossing.
When I first met her in 2016, Barbara recounted visiting her son in the hospital, knowing his injuries were too severe for him to pull through.
“I’m not ready for an apology,” Barbara said, her Cajun accent weighed down with grief. “I want somebody to fix that track. At least that life would have been for something.”
Barbara LeBlanc died earlier this year, before she could learn if anyone will be held responsible for the violent crash.
The Days are still waiting. They said Brandon doesn’t talk about the crash — he never has. He couldn’t even if he wanted to.
The Amtrak train that took his brother, grandmother, step-grandfather and two of his friends also took a chunk of his memory. He doesn’t remember anything from when he left his 12th birthday party at the trampoline park until he woke up in a Baton Rouge hospital.
Keith and Jody Day carry on, trying to stay strong for Brandon. But every milestone he hits reminds them of the son who isn’t here. When Brandon got his driver’s license, Chase, his twin, should have been right beside him.
“It’s been the hardest time of our lives,” Keith Day said. “My little boy, there’s nothing that can bring him back.
“He’s gone, you know.”
Additional reporting was done by Zoe Comerford, Grace Connatser and Jenny Whidden as part of the O’Brien Fellowship. Elizabeth Tew also contributed reporting.

Question:
What does the passage imply about the Federal Railroad Administration's (FRA) capabilities?
A) It has ample funding to enforce all safety guidelines.
B) It has the authority to enforce safety guidelines but lacks the political support.

Question:
What is the main reason for the increase in deaths at railroad crossings in recent years?
A) A decrease in the number of trains.
B) An increase in the number of crossings without safety features.
C) A lack of enforcement of existing safety guidelines.
D) More people choosing to drive at night.

Answer: C) A lack of enforcement of existing safety guidelines.

rd_url:
Long Beach police and fire responded to reports of a collision between a vehicle and an A-Line Metro train near the Anaheim Street Station Friday afternoon.
Officers received the call at 12:40 p.m., according to Sgt. Miguel Valenzuela, and found the 2000 Lexus LS300 wedged between the southbound train and the barrier separating the tracks from the street.
“Once officers arrived at the scene, we escorted everyone off the train,” Valenzuela said.
A 60-year-old female passenger who was on the train heading to Downtown Long Beach when the accident occurred said she and fellow passengers felt a “jolt” when the train collided with the car on the corner of Long Beach Boulevard and 14th Street. Shortly after, the woman—who declined to give her name—said the conductor came to check on her and fellow passengers, but no injuries were reported at the time.
Around 12:50 p.m., passengers could be seen filing out of the train cars toward nearby bus stations.
The driver and passenger of the silver Lexus also reported no injuries. The driver, 53-year-old Rebecca Howard, was visibly shaken by the crash. The Harbor City resident said she was on her way to the nearby Greyhound station, where she planned to embark on a trip to South Carolina to attend her father’s funeral.
“I’m not even gonna make it there now,” Howard said.
After mistaking 14th Street for Anaheim Street, Howard said she made a U-turn, which is when the car collided with the train. Denette Snyder, 47, the owner of the car and a passenger at the time of the crash, said she was scratching off a lottery ticket and didn’t see the train moving toward the car. “I just felt the train hit us,” Snyder said.
Tony Moro, 51, was inspecting tracks nearby when he heard there had been a collision a few blocks north. A veteran of the Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Moro said that for the two people in the vehicle to walk off unscathed was not a common occurrence.
“The stuff I’ve seen, I didn’t even see in the military,” Moro said of other crashes. “That right there, that’s a rare thing.”
Crossing Warning Explanation: The driver made a U-turn from 14th Street to Anaheim Street, not realizing she was there, which led to the collision.

B

Emergency Response Plan for Long Beach Police and Fire Departments:

1. Immediate Notification Protocol:
   - A-Line Metro trains are equipped with an emergency response system that automatically sends alerts to the Long Beach police and fire departments upon detection of a collision.
   - The alert includes the location of the incident, the type of train involved, and any preliminary information available.
   - Upon receiving the alert, the dispatch center immediately notifies all relevant units, including traffic control, hazardous materials teams (if necessary), and specialized rescue services.

2. Scene Assessment Protocol:
   - Dispatch coordinates with train operators to gain insights into the situation and potential hazards.
   - A rapid assessment team, led by experienced personnel, is dispatched to the scene to evaluate the severity of the incident, potential injuries, and immediate risks to safety.
   - The team uses the emergency response system to access real-time data, such as train speed, direction, and passenger count, to inform their assessment.

3. Coordination

The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) has sent three investigators to determine what led to the early Wednesday morning death of a BNSF (NYSE: BRK) worker at the La Mirada rail yard near Los Angeles.
The employee was fatally injured during yard operations. BNSF is cooperating in the investigation.
According to Orange County Fire Authority (OCFA), which received an emergency call at approximately 12:37 a.m. local time, one individual was trapped under a train. OCFA determined after arriving at the scene that two trains had converged and crushed the victim.
“The entire BNSF family is terribly saddened by this event and we extend our deepest sympathy and thoughts to the family and loved ones of the employee involved in this incident,” BNSF said.

LUDLOW, Calif. (AP) — Authorities say a freight train derailed in the Southern California desert on Wednesday, sending more than 40 rail cars crashing into the sand.
The San Bernardino County Fire Department says nobody was hurt and there was no fire when the BNSF train went off the tracks near the remote Mojave community of Ludlow.
Photos and video tweeted by the fire department showed cars piled up along the tracks, some on their sides.
Investigators will try to determine the cause of the crash some150 miles northeast of Los Angeles.

Authorities Thursday identified a homeless woman who was struck by a Metrolink train and killed in Van Nuys.
Erika Cruz Carranza 33, died at the scene of her injuries that occurred about 3 p.m. Wednesday near the 8100 block of North Woodley Avenue, according to the coroner’s office and the Los Angeles Fire Department.
Carranza was apparently walking on the tracks when the train hit her, according to spokesman Nicholas Prange of the LAFD. There was no word of why she was walking on the tracks, nor why she did not hear the sounds of the oncoming deadly train.
No further details about the victim or her death were made available. Officials did not disclose whether they believe her death was intentional or an accident.

A 71-year-old man died after being hit by a train in Fontana on Feb. 18, authorities said.
The incident occurred at 11:58 a.m., when San Bernardino Line Train 325 struck the person who was on the tracks at the Citrus Avenue crossing, a Metrolink spokesperson said.
The man was later identified as Teofilo Moran Lugo, a resident of Fontana, according to the San Bernardino County Sheriff Coroner's Division.
The Fontana Police Department and Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department are investigating the incident.
"The investigation is still ongoing but it looks as if it is a possible suicide or accident," said Officer Kevin Anderson of the Fontana P.D.

rd_url:
This story takes place at a small station named Serra on the Santa Fe Railway’s Los Angeles–San Diego line. One Saturday in the early 1950s, a work train, its work done for the day, was parked on an auxiliary track at the station. As a steam locomotive—oil-fired Mikado No. 3139—was the power for the work train, it was necessary to have an engine watchman present to keep steam pressure up during the time the work train was not working and the crew was getting their rest. The engine watchman’s job was not very desirable, and consequently fell to the lowest fireman on the seniority list.
The station at Serra was a picturesque little structure of white stucco with a red clay tile roof, located on the west end of a sweeping 50-mph curve, with the first panoramic view of the Pacific Ocean that one gets from the train as the railroad joins the surf on its way to San Diego.
The young engine watchman, sent down from Los Angeles, arrived at Serra on Saturday evening to watch the work train engine for Saturday night and Sunday. The engine had to be ready to go to work early Monday morning. The watchman’s duties were minimal, keeping pressure at a workable level, water in the boiler, and supplying the engine with sand and lubricating oil. Steam pressure was maintained by periodically starting up the fire, building up steam pressure so that the water injectors would work to supply water to the boiler, then putting the fire out. The engine then needed little attention for two or three hours as its steam pressure and boiler-water level slowly dropped. Then the procedure would be repeated to build up steam and boiler-water level again. (Unlike coal-fired engines, oil-burners can have their fires started or extinguished quickly.)
The job was boring. A young man might be tempted to briefly slip away from his post in search of some diversion, yet there surely was not much going on at Serra on a Saturday night. However, on the big Marine Corps Air Base at Irvine, a station about seven miles west of Serra, there was a USO dance on Saturday nights.
The young fireman at this point apparently decided—contrary to railroad rules—that he could build up steam pressure and fill the boiler with water, put out the fire, and leave the engine for a few hours. He could drive to the Marine base, spend a couple of hours at the dance, and get back to the engine in time to build up the steam pressure that had leaked down.
The exact sequence of events, and the duration of the watchman’s absence, will never be known for sure. But what apparently happened is that when he returned to the locomotive, he got up into the cab and noticed the steam pressure had dropped considerably. He immediately started the fire in the firebox to start rebuilding the steam pressure. Either he did not check the water level in the boiler, or he thought he could see water in the water glass gauge without checking the positive gauge cocks. Sometimes the water glasses would get stopped up with boiler sediment and register a higher-than-actual water level.
With a big fire going, the crown sheet of boiler firebox attained a very high temperature. At this time, the fireman decided to start the injector to replenish the water supply to the boiler. The injector syphons water from the locomotive tender—which is very cold relative to the boiler interior—into the boiler to produce steam.
Most everyone knows what happens to drops of water that fall into a hot skillet on the stove; imagine this reaction magnified thousands of times. When the cold water hit the white-hot crown sheet of the boiler, there was a tremendous explosion. The boiler separated from the frame and traveled through the air like a giant projectile. It hit the roof of the Serra depot, tore off the top of the roof, and landed about 200 yards away from where the locomotive was. The track under the engine was blown away, forming a large crater. Parts of the locomotive were strewn around in all directions. Needless to say, as is nearly always the case with boiler explosions, the young engine watchman did not survive this violent destruction.
Boiler explosions were rare in the later decades of the steam era, yet they were grimly memorable. I passed the scene of this accident the next day on train N076 to San Diego. The destruction and tremendous power of the explosion, the only one whose aftermath I ever witnessed, remains vivid in my memory today, several decades later.
First published in Spring 2009 Classic Trains magazine.
Learn more about railroad history by signing up for the Classic Trains e-mail newsletter. It’s a free monthly e-mail devoted to the golden years of railroading.

MAURICEVILLE, Texas -- A train derailment near the Texas-Louisiana border Thursday forced two schools to evacuate and motorists to scramble as the cars left the tracks in front of them.
It happened in Mauriceville, a town of approximately 3,200 in Orange County on tracks owned by Kansas City Southern Railroad.
The train consisted of 25 rail cars, according to the Orange County Sheriff's Office. 15 of the cars were loaded, including five tank cars that were breached.
Four tank cars were carrying petroleum-based products and another car contained a product described by the sheriff's office as corrosive, though it was not clear what exactly was on board.
The sheriff's office said there was no risk to the area, though a 1-mile evacuation zone was established.
Video of the incident showed multiple rail cars leaving the tracks that run parallel to a two-lane road. A cloud of smoke could be seen billowing above the wreckage.
WATCH: Derailment caught on camera
Two Mauriceville school campuses were part of the evacuation zone Thursday morning. Approximately 600 people were impacted by the orders to stay away, the sheriff's office said.
Hazardous materials crews were on the scene cleaning up the wreckage and spill.
Mauriceville is approximately 100 miles east of Houston.

rd_url:
'A Miracle That I'm Standing Here': Man Calls For More LA Metro Safety Measures After Train Collision
VERNON (CBSLA) -- John Moss was driving along Long Beach Avenue at 55th Street in Los Angeles on March 2, on his way to pick up his work partner early in the morning. He says he made a left hand turn, across a set of L.A. Metro train tracks — and had no idea a train was speeding his way.
"No indications that the lights were blinking and I didn't hear any bells, it was too late," he said. "I looked to the left and a train just hit me. Next thing I knew, I basically woke up in the hospital."
Security footage shows the incident. The train hits Moss' BMW at full speed as he tries to make his turn.
"It's a miracle that I'm standing here and I have nightmares about this," he said. "I'm very lucky to be alive."
The 60-year-old suffered broken bones and major internal injuries. He said he continues to deal with pain, but he is thankful to be alive to tell his story.
"Fortunate for me, I got hit on the left side of my car and the train pushed me back out and that's how the car did not end up on the tracks," he said. "If I didn't survive that accident, no one would know about this."
He said he believes his accident could have been prevented, and he wants to see changes before other drivers are hurt or killed.
"I was allowed to enter the intersection and there was no gate to stop me from entering the intersection," he said.
A spokesperson for the L.A. Metro said they performed a post-accident inspection their equipment and found that all warning lights, crossing gates, and warning bells were functioning at the time of the accident. They also said the driver made an illegal left turn and used the wrong traffic lane to circumvent the lowered crossing gate.
"Regardless of what they're saying about I entered on the wrong lane, no one should be allowed to enter period," Moss said about the statement.
"They should've came up with the conclusion that this is a very dangerous intersection," he said. "What happened to me, it's easy to happen to someone else. Those changes are a necessity."

SAN PEDRO, LOS ANGELES (KABC) -- An engineer deliberately ran a train off the tracks at high speed near the Port of Los Angeles in an attempt to crash into the USNS Mercy hospital ship, prosecutors say.
The Pacific Harbor Line train derailed Tuesday, running through the end of the track and crashing through barriers, finally coming to rest about 250 yards from the docked naval ship.
Federal prosecutors allege train engineer Eduardo Moreno, 44, of San Pedro intended to hit the ship, saying he thought it was "suspicious" and did not believe "the ship is what they say it's for.'"
The train crashed into a concrete barrier at the end of the track, smashed through a steel barrier and a chain-link fence, slid through one parking lot and then a second lot filled with gravel and hit a second chain-link fence. It came to rest after passing under a ramp leading to the Vincent Thomas Bridge. The train remained in that position Wednesday.
No one was injured in the derailment, but the train leaked fuel that required a hazmat response.
Authorities say Moreno admitted to crashing the train intentionally, but said he did not plan it out in advance. It is believed that he acted alone.
He allegedly made statements to a CHP officer that included "You only get this chance once. The whole world is watching. I had to. People don't know what's going on here. Now they will."
Officials say video from inside the train's cab shows Moreno holding a lighted flare during the incident.
Moreno has been charged with one count of train wrecking, according to the U.S. Attorney's Office. The charge carries a maximum penalty of 20 years in federal prison.
The Mercy arrived at the Port of Los Angeles this weekend.
The Navy hospital ship was brought in to handle non-coronavirus patients, to help ease the burden of local hospitals that are surging with COVID-19 cases.
The ship has about 1,000 hospital beds, with some 800 active-duty doctors, nurses and medical staff on board. It is expected to stay in Los Angeles at least until September or until it is no longer needed.

SANTA FE SPRINGS, Calif. — No injuries were reported when a Metrolink train hit a motor home at a grade crossing, setting the vehicle on fire and badly damaging the commuter train’s cab car.
The accident occurred near the intersection of Rosecrans and Marquardt avenues, involving train No. 681, the morning’s first inbound Orange County Line train. That train is scheduled to depart Laguna Niguel/Mission Viejo at 4:05 a.m. and arrive at Los Angeles Union Station at 5:25 a.m., but KTLA-5 News reports the accident occurred at about 5:45 a.m.
As of 7:45 a.m. local time, tracks remained out of service between Santa Fe Springs and Buena Park. Metrolink was running some bus service, but was advising passengers to seek alternate transportation. Updated information is available on Metrolink’s Twitter account.

rd_url:
SANTA FE SPRINGS, Calif. -- A recreational vehicle that was left on train tracks in Santa Fe Springs was struck by a Metrolink train and burst into flames Friday morning.
Authorities say the fiery collision occurred shortly after 5:30 a.m. near the intersection of Rosecrans and Marquardt avenues. Fire crews believe the RV stalled at the Rosecrans Avenue intersection and was struck by the OC Line 681, which was carrying over 100 passengers and was heading from Orange County to Los Angeles.
Dramatic video shared on social media shows the moment the train slammed into the RV and pushed it along the track. The video appears to show people fleeing from the RV, and witnesses told police four people were seen running from the site of the collision moments before the crash.
Firefighters were seen dousing flames that gutted the vehicle and charred a rail car. Smoke from the fire could be seen for several miles.
Flames engulf Metrolink train after crash on tracks in Santa Fe Springs
"We got buffeted around pretty good, and it felt like we might derail for a second or two," train passenger Mike Lozano said.
Shortly after the collision, a freight train arrived on the parallel tracks.
"You could hear it coming, and it was coming really fast, you could tell," Lozano said.
Another passenger said he braced for potential impact as he heard the sound of the freight train quickly approaching.
"That was honestly the longest few seconds of my life, like when I heard the train horn coming, I was just looking around, everyone was looking around, are we even going to be safe? Do they know that this just happened? Because it sounded like they didn't," Ryan Hajek described.
The freight train ran over debris from the crash before coming to a stop as the fire from the Metrolink train started to spread.
AIR7 HD was over the scene, where dozens of evacuated passengers waited in a nearby parking lot while crews battled the flames. Four passengers who suffered minor injuries were treated and later released, according to officials.
"The hit was such an impact on the train," passenger Rosalind Carter said. "I remember being flung into the seat next to me, I hit my head, it was just pretty traumatic."
WATCH: Passenger describes frightening experience following Metrolink crash
The crash caused significant train delays and cancellations. Metrolink offered ticket reimbursements for some customers and advised affected passengers to find their own transportation as "alternate" transportation was limited.
Many passengers who frequently ride the train said the crash could've been a lot worse but were thankful for the quick response of Metrolink employees and first responders.
"I got a couple more weeks of work, I'm retiring in December. So yeah, just wanna get through this thing and come out on the other end," Lozano said.
A search is underway for the occupants of the RV, who may face hit-and-run charges.

rd_url:
Metrolink train strikes RV in Santa Fe Springs, shutting down several trains to Los Angeles
An investigation was underway Friday morning after a Metrolink passenger train collided with a vehicle in Santa Fe Springs.
- Share via
Firefighters worked quickly to extinguish a blaze that ignited after a Metrolink commuter train collided with a recreational vehicle in Santa Fe Springs before dawn Friday.
The crash occurred just before 6 a.m. near Rosecrans and Marquardt avenues, said Eric Ortiz, a spokesman for the Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department. The commuter train, RV and an adjacent freight train all caught fire.
Metrolink spokesman Scott Johnson said 120 passengers were on the Orange County 681 Line train headed toward Los Angeles at the time of the crash. No passengers were injured and everyone was evacuated safely, Johnson said. The train operator, who was closest to the collision, is also safe, he said. It was not immediately clear whether anyone in the RV was injured.
All trains that run along the same tracks, including the Perris Valley 91 Line and Amtrak’s Pacific Surfliner trains, will experience delays. Johnson said Metrolink does not have an estimate for how long delays will be.
Passengers aboard the 681 Line and the trains that followed, including the 601 and the 603, can receive a voucher for ride-hailing services because of the delays. Evacuated passengers were being bused to Union Station.
“Passengers who typically take one of those lines into Los Angeles may want to consider alternate transportation this morning,” he said. “We don’t anticipate this to be a quick clearance.”
Johnson said he did not have details about the circumstances of the collision. The Whittier Police Department is investigating.
By 6:35 a.m., the flames had been extinguished, leaving behind the charred RV. Video showed fire officials entering the front of the Metronlink train, which was significantly damaged in the blaze.

Fire ignites after Metrolink train strikes motorhome on its tracks in Santa Fe Springs
SANTA FE SPRINGS, Calif. - A vehicle erupted in flames after it was struck by a Metrolink train on its tracks in Santa Fe Springs on Friday morning, authorities said.
The OC Line 681 was headed toward Union Station in downtown Los Angeles when the crash occurred at the intersection of Rosecrans and Marquardt avenues just after 6 a.m.
"I had my headphones on, so I didn't hear anything, but there was a big bump before the train stopped completely and people were rattled. The lights went out for about 30 seconds or so. We all started looking outside the window and saw debris on the track," a passenger aboard the train when it crashed told FOX 11.
All tracks between Buena Park and Norwalk Santa Fe Springs were closed until further notice. Metrolink apologized to passengers for the inconvenience as a result of the fiery crash.
(LASD)
Officials said 300 people were aboard the train and were evacuated safely. Buses were deployed to transport passengers to an alternative station.
The RV was abandoned at the time of the crash and four passengers sustained minor injuries. They were treated and released, officials said.

rd_url:
Deadly train crash in Egypt happened because two conductors were brawling
- Share via
Reporting from Cairo — A fight between two train conductors unleashed a speeding, unmanned locomotive that slammed into a barrier and exploded in the Egyptian capital’s main train station Wednesday, killing at least 25 people, authorities said.
Railway officials said the single railcar collided head-on with the buffer stop, causing a huge explosion and fire. At least 47 people were also injured, many of them critically, and officials said the death toll could rise.
The deadly blaze blasted through people on the platform in the busy Ramses Station in downtown Cairo. A surveillance video showed the moment of impact when the car barreled past men and women walking by and engulfed them in flames and smoke. Charred bodies lay on the platform, and a man in flames ran down a staircase in panic, according to other photos and videos posted on social media.
Egyptian prosecutor General Nabil Sadek said investigators determined the locomotive’s conductor had left his car to fight with another conductor whose railcar was blocking his.
But the conductor left without putting on the brakes, and the other car began moving backward, freeing the locomotive, which then gathered speed and hit the concrete-and-metal barrier, exploding.
“The driver left the railcar without taking any measures to brake it,” Sadek said in a statement.
Sadek put the death toll at 20 while health officials said at least 25 people had been killed and dozens more injured in the crash and ensuing fire. Some of the bodies were burned beyond recognition, and DNA tests were carried out to determine identities.
The driver of the railcar has been under interrogation, and Sadek said the investigation was continuing.
The deadly accident prompted Transportation Minister Hisham Arafat to resign his post, according to a statement released by the Cabinet office.
The Ramses district is among the busiest and most crowded areas of Cairo. The state railway agency briefly halted all train traffic and ordered the evacuation of the station.
The accident triggered an online debate among Egyptians, with many blaming the government for not improving railway services, even after a series of deadly accidents. Several noted previous statements by President Abdel Fattah Sisi arguing about spending billions of pounds on improving trains.
Video from surveillance cameras showed flames ravaging the station’s interior. One video that surfaced on social media showed men and women carrying bags and personal belongings and walking on the rail platforms as the train car crashed and exploded.
Another showed men and women running and searching for exits after the explosion. A man is seen running back and forth, his shirt on fire, until another man rushes to pour water on him.
A weakened opposition resists push to keep Egypt’s Sisi in power until 2034 »
Mohammed Said, head of the Cairo railways hospital, said at least 25 people were killed but that the death toll could rise.
Many of the wounded were in critical condition, mostly suffering severe burns, said Egyptian Health Minister Hala Zayed.
Prime Minister Mustafa Madbouli vowed harsh punishment for those behind the accident.
Egypt’s railway system has a history of badly maintained equipment and poor management. Official figures show that 1,793 train accidents took place in 2017 across the country.
In July 2018, a passenger train derailed near the southern city of Aswan, injuring at least six people and prompting authorities to fire the chief of the country’s railways.
In March last year, Sisi said the government lacked about 250 billion Egyptian pounds, or $14.1 billion, to overhaul the run-down rail system. He spoke a day after a passenger train collided with a cargo train, killing at least 12 people, including a child.
In August 2017, two passenger trains collided in northern Egypt, just outside the Mediterranean port city of Alexandria, killing 43 people. In 2016, at least 51 people were killed when two commuter trains collided near Cairo.
The deadliest train crash took place in 2002 when more 300 people were killed when fire erupted in a speeding train traveling from Cairo to southern Egypt.

rd_url:
Nearly 200 Amtrak passengers stranded for over 24 hours on Oregon train
An Amtrak train that hit a downed tree in Oregon stranded 183 passengers for more than 24 hours.
The Coast Starlight train, headed to Los Angeles from Seattle, stopped in Oakridge, Oregon, around 6:20 p.m. Sunday. By Monday night, passengers remained stuck inside the train as heavy snow and road closures in the area reportedly made it difficult to get to them.
Amtrak chief operating officer Scot Naparstek told USA TODAY in a statement that the company worked with local resources to rescue the passengers, who were en route to Eugene, Oregon, on Tuesday morning. The company said no one was injured.
"With more than a foot of heavy snow and numerous trees blocking the track, we made every decision in the best interest of the safety of our customers during the unfortunate sequence of events," Naparstek said. "With local power outages and blocked roads, it was decided the safest place for our customers was to remain on the train where we were able to provide food, heat, electricity and toilets."
Passenger Rebekah Dodson shared a Facebook live video, photos and a plea for help from the train.
"Please, if anyone is out there, share. I am one of the 183 stranded...35 hours and counting... No rescue in sight," she posted early Tuesday morning.
Just before 8 a.m. on Tuesday, Dodson tweeted "we have an engine!"
Kim Song, the mother of a stranded passenger, told KATU that Amtrak staff told her daughter she'd be charged for a blanket while waiting for help on the train. Other passengers reported being charged for food, a claim the company said wasn't true.
Naparstek said Amtrak will be contacting customers to provide refunds and "other compensation as appropriate."
Contributing: Associated Press. Follow Ashley May on Twitter: @AshleyMayTweets
